content.title: Type narrowing in Typescript
content.summary:
Very often we need to be able to differentiate between Typescript interfaces which have some properties in common. This is known as "type narrowing". We are going to cover 3 basic ways of performing type narrowing in Typescript.

Let's start with the following example:

interface Vehicle {
    weight: number;
    wheels?: number;
    class?: 'A' | '1' | '2' |'3';
}

In our application we have different vehicles. For trucks, for

content.title: Probability definitions
content.summary:
Probability definitions

Let \(\Omega\) be a set.

Def 1. A \(\sigma\)-field is a collection \(\mathcal{F}\) of subsets of \(\Omega\) such that \(\emptyset \in \mathcal{F}\), and it's closed under complementation and under countable unions.

Def 2. The sets that are members of \(\mathcal{F}\) are said to be measurable with respect to \(\mathcal{F}\), or just measurable

content.title: Ross' Introduction to Probability Models - Ex 3.11
content.summary:
Ross' Introduction to Probability Models - Ex 3.11

A coin, having probability p of coming up heads, is to be successively flipped until the first head appears. What is the expected number of flips required?

First of all, let us define a probability space \( (\Omega, \mathcal{F}, P)\) for this problem.

  • \( \Omega = \left\{ (w_1, w_2, w_3, \ldots) \mid w_i \in \{0, 1\}, \, i = 1, 2, \ldots \right\}\). Each of t
